visibility_factors: very low clouds/possible dense fog pockets

alert_summary.description: NWS Grand Rapids advisory indicates slick roads/bridges and rapidly changing visibility for the Wed night–Thu morning commute; Rockford is near the advisory area, so impacts could clip the area even if totals are light.

meteorology.overall_conditions_summary: For Thursday 2026-01-29 in Rockford, MI: snow accumulation is not the issue (forecast total snow ~0"), but a short pre-dawn window of light freezing rain (roughly 1–5 AM) combined with extreme cold (temps near/below 0°F, wind chills near -5 to -10°F) raises the risk of glazed/black-ice conditions—especially on untreated roads, bridges, and sidewalks. Winds stay light, so blowing/drifting is not a factor, and any precip ends early enough that plows/salt crews have time to improve main roads before the morning commute. The biggest school-impact signal here is visibility: multiple hours show near-zero visibility late night/early morning and again late evening with freezing fog, which can make rural and back-road travel hazardous even without significant snow. Overall: low-to-moderate snow-day potential, but elevated delay/closure risk if freezing drizzle/fog verifies and untreated surfaces become icy around bus pickup time.

similar_weather_patterns.pattern_description: Light lake-effect/in-and-out bands the evening before into the early-morning commute window (advisory-level totals ~1–3 inches), followed by colder/drier stabilization and little/no additional daytime accumulation. This often produces uneven road conditions—fine on main roads, slick on untreated neighborhood/side roads—without meeting district-wide closure thresholds.

Trace-to-light freezing drizzle/freezing rain overnight at very cold surface temps (single digits °F, wind chills near/under 0°F), creating thin glaze on bridges/ramps and untreated lots. In West Michigan, this can prompt delays more often than full closures unless icing is widespread and coincides with heavy traffic timing.

Cold, calm/high-pressure day after a minor event: temps well below freezing but limited new precip and modest wind. Typically a normal school day unless residual slick spots plus fog/low visibility are significant at bus time.

seasonal_context.typical_conditions_for_date: Late January in the Rockford (Kent County) area is peak winter: routine sub-freezing temps, frequent lake-effect variability, and schools generally remain open through light-moderate snow if roads can be treated. Closures are most common with (a) widespread ice, (b) true blizzard conditions with heavy snow/wind/whiteouts, or (c) extreme cold/wind chills roughly below -15°F that create safety/transport issues.
unusual_factors: Overnight/early-morning signal for light freezing rain/freezing fog while surface temps are well below 32°F (thin glaze risk on bridges/untreated roads).
Very low vis values are indicated in parts of the night/morning and again late evening (fog/ice fog). Even without snow, visibility plus slick spots can affect buses.

Despite advisories in nearby lakeshore counties, the provided point forecast shows minimal total precip at Rockford itself—suggesting banded/spotty impacts where a 10–20 mile shift can change outcomes.

local_microclimates: West Michigan lake-effect bands can set up NW–WNW flow and produce sharp gradients: Rockford can see brief heavier bursts while areas a few miles away see little.
River valleys/low-lying areas around the Rogue River can trap colder air and support freezing fog, increasing localized slickness on secondary roads.
infrastructure_considerations: Major routes (US-131 corridors via access routes, M-44/Knapp vicinity, and primary arterials) are usually treated and passable unless snowfall rates are high at commute time.
Neighborhood/subdivision roads and rural bus routes can stay slick longer—this is where delays are more likely than full closures on marginal events.
Bridges/overpasses cool faster and are the first to glaze if any freezing drizzle occurs.
location_specific_factors.elevation_impact: Minor rolling-terrain effects: small elevation changes can influence fog/icing pockets, but not enough to drive a countywide closure by itself.

history.confidence_assessment: For Thursday 2026-01-29 specifically, the forecast at Rockford shows very cold temperatures (min near -5°F, daytime teens) but essentially no meaningful snow accumulation and only very light precip. Michigan districts rarely close for cold alone unless wind chills are extreme (<~ -15°F) or there is a major safety hazard; here wind is modest (generally under ~7 mph), so wind chills are cold but not in the classic extreme-closure range. The main closure-worthy risk in this dataset is not snow depth but a narrow overnight window of light freezing rain/freezing fog plus low visibility that could create patchy glaze for the morning commute. Net: a full snow day looks unlikely; a delay is the more plausible outcome if early-morning icing/visibility verifies on untreated roads and bus routes. Overall confidence is medium because lake-effect and icing are highly sensitive to small shifts, and the advisory text suggests localized heavier impacts are possible even if the point forecast totals remain low.

safety_recommendations: Primary risk is ice, not snow: even very light freezing rain overnight can glaze bridges/overpasses and untreated neighborhood roads; assume isolated black ice for the 06:00–08:00 commute.
Prioritize treatment/plowing resources on bridges, curves, hills, and known trouble spots before 06:00; main arterials should recover faster given Michigan’s overnight operations.
Expect the biggest variability on secondary/subdivision streets and rural connectors; bus routes that rely on those roads should be assessed early (by ~05:30–06:00).
Parking lots, sidewalks, and drop-off loops may be slick at opening due to overnight freezing rain and very cold pavement temps; increase salt use and allow extra time for custodial crews.

Visibility flags in the hourly feed show near-zero at times overnight and again late evening (freezing fog); even if sky clears at 07:00–08:00, plan for patchy low-visibility pockets and reduced contrast on roads.
Extreme cold (near -5°F air, wind chills around -5 to -10°F) increases risk for students at stops; ensure winter gear messaging and consider warming plans for prolonged waits/delays.

local_news.headline: Dozens of schools closed Wednesday for freezing weather (includes Rockford Public Schools and neighboring districts)
local_news.summary: FOX 17 reported widespread closures across West Michigan on Wednesday, Jan. 28, 2026 due to freezing weather and snowy road conditions, explicitly listing Rockford Public Schools along with nearby/peer districts like Forest Hills Public Schools, Grand Rapids Public Schools, Kentwood Public Schools, and others. This suggests broad regional impacts and a “domino effect” environment where multiple districts are reacting to similar conditions.

local_news.headline: Plow drivers work eight consecutive days as heavy snow blankets Kent County (Rockford/Cedar Springs/Sparta mentioned)
local_news.summary: FOX 17 described significant snowfall impacts in Kent County, saying residents in Cedar Springs, Sparta, and Rockford woke up Tuesday to school closures and nearly 6 inches of new snow, with plow drivers dealing with whiteout/drifting conditions. This is strong context that road conditions have been meaningfully degraded recently in the Rockford area.

local_news.headline: School Closing Outlook for Wednesday 01/28/2026 (issued Tue 01/27/2026)
local_news.summary: Their outlook for Wednesday noted lingering lake-effect snow impacts and specifically highlighted that isolated closures/delays could occur due to poor secondary road conditions, especially in rural areas near/west of US-131. While this outlook is for Wednesday (Jan. 28), it’s a signal that road-condition uncertainty (secondary roads) is a key factor in this pattern for the Rockford/US-131 corridor area.

local_news.headline: Supporters outlook posted for Thursday 01/29/2026 & Friday 01/30/2026 (exists; details paywalled until later)
local_news.summary: West Michigan Weather shows a dedicated outlook post for Thursday, Jan. 29, 2026 and Friday, Jan. 30, 2026 (posted Wed Jan. 28, 2026 mid-afternoon). The content is paywalled at the time of crawl, but the existence/timing indicates they expect enough ongoing interest/impact to warrant specific closure guidance for Thursday in West Michigan.

news.key_findings_summary: For Rockford, MI (Rockford Public Schools) heading into Thursday, 2026-01-29: the strongest available signals are (1) widespread regional school closures already occurring Wednesday, Jan. 28 (FOX 17 explicitly listed Rockford Public Schools and neighboring districts), and (2) confirmed significant snowfall/whiteout/drifting impacts in the Rockford/Cedar Springs/Sparta area earlier in the week with heavy plow operations (FOX 17). Community chatter on r/grandrapids aligns with hazardous driving and poor visibility on major corridors (notably US-131) during the storm window. I did not find a clearly posted official Rockford Public Schools announcement specifically for Thursday, Jan. 29 on the district site at the time checked, and the WestMichiganWeather.net Thursday outlook exists but was paywalled in the crawl. Overall, local-road-condition impacts and the ongoing regional closure pattern are the most relevant context signals for a potential Thursday closure/delay decision.

county_roads.estimated_clear_time: County primary/arterial network should be in serviceable winter condition by ~06:30 AM Thu 2026-01-29; expect hard-packed/slick spots at intersections/hills/curves to persist into the morning.

local_streets.estimated_clear_time: Residential/local streets likely variable by 06:30 AM Thu 2026-01-29 (better on well-traveled routes, worse in subdivisions/low-volume streets). Expect lingering hard-pack/ice due to limited melting.

clearing_timeline.snow_end_time: Thu 2026-01-29 ~06:00 AM (per provided hourly forecast: freezing rain signal mainly 01:00–05:00 with very light QPF; then overcast/clearing)
clearing_timeline.estimated_road_condition_at_6_30_am: Most primary roads and trunklines near Rockford (Kent County) should be drivable but not ‘bare pavement’: expect slick spots, hard-packed snow, and especially treacherous bridges/overpasses and untreated neighborhood streets. Extreme cold limits chemical effectiveness and prevents melt-off.

infrastructure.overall_clearing_assessment: Given KCRC’s ongoing operations (scraping/pushing back snow and applying abrasives at known traction points) and the forecast showing minimal additional accumulation, widespread impassability is unlikely by 06:30 AM Thursday. The bigger risk for bus routes is patchy black ice/hard-pack from very cold temps plus a brief period of light freezing precipitation overnight. Expect ‘winter driving’ conditions rather than a clean/fully bare-road morning; delays are more plausible than a full closure unless conditions worsen overnight or localized icing/fog significantly reduces visibility.

Road clearing outlook: main routes likely serviceable by ~06:00–07:30, but local/subdivision streets remain inconsistent hard-pack/ice—this favors a DELAY more than a full closure

timeline.conditions_start: 2026-01-29 01:00 (onset of light freezing drizzle/freezing rain risk)

final.decision_rationale:
Pre-decision checklist synthesis:
1) Agreement across experts: (a) snow totals are not the issue; (b) a pre-dawn icing window is the main risk; (c) primary roads improve by the morning commute but secondary/local roads stay variable; (d) wind chills are cold but not at the near-automatic closure threshold.
2) Disagreements: the only major conflict was the API’s near-zero visibility values vs other sources. Web verification did not corroborate dense fog at 06:00–08:00, suggesting the ‘0 mi’ entries are likely invalid/missing rather than true whiteout fog.
3) Plow timing math: freezing precip risk ~01:00–05:00; effective ‘melt’ is limited due to very cold pavement, so the key is abrasives/traction. By 06:00–07:30, trunklines/primaries should be moving, while local/subdivision streets remain inconsistent—this profile usually produces DELAYS more than district-wide closures.
4) Ice? Yes—this is the core concern. Even light glaze can create bus-route failures on hills/bridges.
5) Neighboring districts: prior-day closures were widespread, but there is no confirmed Thursday closure wave yet (closings list and district sites show no postings at check time). So I do not apply the +15–20% ‘3+ neighboring districts closed’ bump for Thursday.
6) Power outages: not currently present at meaningful scale; grid stress is elevated with conservation messaging, but that’s not a direct closure trigger absent outages at schools.
7) Wind chill verification: no multi-source confirmation of ≤ -20°F.
8) What would make this wrong: (a) icing is more widespread than forecast (trace becomes a real glaze) especially on secondary roads, (b) an unexpected dense freezing fog forms right at bus time, (c) an early ‘domino’ closure wave starts overnight and Rockford follows.

Weighting the experts per directive: Meteorology (25%) and Safety (25%) dominate because this is an ice/commute-timing event; both point to ‘delay more likely than closure.’ History (15%) supports that trace icing events more often yield delays. News intel (15%) adds upward pressure from recent closure momentum, but lacks confirmed Thursday closure signals tonight. Infrastructure (10%) indicates main roads likely serviceable by ~06:00–07:30 but locals remain problematic. Power (5%) is a minor add (grid stress, but no outages). Web verifier (5%) reduces closure odds by downgrading the dense-fog/visibility-zero concern.

Net: I’m setting a 30% chance of a FULL closure (snow day). The most likely operational outcome is a 2-hour delay rather than closure, driven by patchy black ice on bus routes.

alternative_scenarios.scenario: Most likely: 2-hour delay (AM bus safety/ice checks), then normal day
alternative_scenarios.impact: Improves safety margin while crews treat intersections/bridges and daylight increases visibility/contrast.

alternative_scenarios.scenario: Open on time (ice patchy and treated; no fog; roads acceptable)
alternative_scenarios.impact: Normal operations; emphasize slow travel and slip hazards at stops/parking lots.

alternative_scenarios.scenario: Full closure (widespread glaze or sudden dense freezing fog at 06:00–08:00; multiple nearby districts close)
alternative_scenarios.impact: District-wide transportation risk too high; closure likely announced early morning.

for_schools: Plan for a likely DELAY decision framework: run early-morning route checks focusing on hills/bridges/subdivision connectors; set an internal go/no-go target by ~05:30–06:00.
If opening, prioritize salting/sanding: bus loops, drop-off lanes, sidewalks, and entrances (glare ice risk on packed surfaces).
Prepare cold-exposure mitigation (warming areas, shortened outdoor waiting if buses run late).
Monitor neighboring district calls between ~04:30–06:30; if a closure wave starts AND local icing reports are widespread, be ready to escalate from delay to closure.
for_residents: Assume black ice 05:30–08:00, especially on bridges/overpasses and neighborhood streets; allow extra stopping distance.
Dress for very cold waiting at stops; have a backup plan for delayed buses.
If you encounter widespread glaze in subdivisions, report it (local police/road commission channels) to help route decisions.
for_authorities: Target abrasives to bridges, curves, hills, and stop-controlled intersections before 06:00; re-hit known trouble spots around 06:00–07:30.
If possible, publish/boost real-time condition updates for secondary roads (the main uncertainty driver).
Coordinate with school transportation supervisors on the worst local-road corridors for priority treatment.

positions.rationale: Meteorologically, Thu 2026-01-29 looks like a post-event cold, mostly dry day in Rockford with a narrow pre-dawn icing window. That setup more often produces a 2-hour delay than a full closure: impacts are patchy (bridges/side streets) and improve after sunrise, with no heavy snow rates or wind-driven visibility collapse. I’m assigning a non-trivial closure probability mainly because (a) any freezing drizzle at sub-5°F pavement temps can create widespread ‘invisible’ black ice quickly, and (b) the hourly feed’s near-zero visibility signals—if real at 06:00–08:00—can force a conservative call for buses. Still, the lack of meaningful new snow and light winds keeps the closure probability below ~25%.
keyFactors: Minimal additional accumulation on Thu 2026-01-29 (day total precip ~0.09 mm; totalsnow 0): low likelihood of a “snow” closure driver.

Main operational risk is *ice*, not snow: several pre-dawn hours (roughly 01:00–05:00) flagged as light freezing rain with temps ~2°F down to ~-4°F → thin glaze/black-ice potential, especially bridges/untreated neighborhood roads.

Visibility is a wildcard: multiple hours show extremely low/near-zero visibility (likely fog/ice fog or model artifact). If dense freezing fog verifies around bus time, it can elevate risk disproportionally even without snowfall.
Winds are light (max ~6–7 mph) → no blowing/drifting/whiteout mechanism; also wind chills mostly around ~-5 to -10°F, which is cold but usually not “close for cold alone” territory in West Michigan.
Timing favors treatment: precip/visibility worst looks overnight; if roads are treated effectively before ~06:00–07:00, many districts can run normally (or go delay instead of closure).

positions.rationale: From a history/precedent lens, Thursday looks like a ‘marginal’ closure setup: very cold, but not extreme-wind-chill cold; minimal new snow; and the main risk concentrated in patchy ice/fog around the early commute. Those scenarios in West Michigan typically lead to a 2-hour delay or selective/rural-route impacts more than a district-wide snow day. The reason I’m still at ~20% (not single digits) is the recent run of closures and degraded baseline conditions—districts sometimes extend caution if residual hard-pack/black ice persists and the overnight glaze verifies.
keyFactors: Historical closure behavior in West Michigan: districts usually *do not* close for cold alone unless wind chills reach a more extreme threshold (often ~-15°F to -20°F+ in practice). Here, winds are light and the “feels like” is mostly around roughly -5°F to -10°F—uncomfortable but not a classic closure trigger.
No meaningful new snow is forecast for Thu 2026-01-29 at the Rockford point location (day totals ~0"), so the usual “plowable snow” driver for a full closure is absent.

The *historical* driver that can still create closures on low-snow days is ice + timing. There’s an overnight 01:00–05:00 window flagged as light freezing rain/freezing drizzle and multiple hours with very low visibility/freezing fog risk. Historically, that pattern produces *delays more often than full-day cancellations* unless the icing is widespread.

Context matters: news signals say many districts (including Rockford) closed Wed 2026-01-28, and earlier in the week there were reports of heavier snow in the area. Historically that raises the odds of “domino-effect” cautious decisions the next morning if roads haven’t fully recovered—so I’m not as low as a pure forecast-only model would be.

positions.rationale: From a safety standpoint, the forecast does not scream “snow day” on accumulation, but it does present a credible **pre-dawn icing + low-visibility** risk window on Thu 2026-01-29 that can make transportation decisions fail on the margins (buses, student drivers, staff commutes). Because impacts appear **patchy/localized** and likely improve after sunrise, I land in the “more likely delay than closure” zone—yet not low enough to ignore, given the severe cold and visibility flags. Net: ~28% chance of a full snow day/closure, with higher probability for a delay.
keyFactors: Primary safety risk is **ice + visibility**, not snowfall: several pre-dawn hours show *light freezing rain* with temps well below 0°F (e.g., ~1–5 AM Thu 2026-01-29) and multiple hours show **very low/near-zero visibility** (fog/ice fog). This combination can produce patchy but high-consequence hazards on bridges, curves, and untreated secondary roads—exactly where buses operate.

**Timing aligns with bus/commute window**: worst conditions are forecast roughly **01:00–06:30**, which overlaps pre-trip inspections and early routes; even if arterials improve, rural connectors and subdivision streets can remain slick at pickup time.

**Extreme cold increases consequence and slows improvement**: low near **-5°F** limits salt effectiveness and prevents melt-off; delays or road incidents become more consequential for kids at stops and for transportation recovery.

**Recent regional closures + ongoing advisories nearby** raise the “risk tolerance” for running buses. Even if Rockford isn’t explicitly named in the advisory excerpt, nearby advisory language about slick roads/rapidly changing vis is relevant to the commute-risk decision.

Counterweights against a full closure: **very low QPF** (minimal new precip), **light winds** (no blowing/drifting), and expectation that **primary roads should be serviceable by ~06:30** with ongoing operations—this pattern often yields a delay rather than a closure.

positions.rationale: From a news/decision-pattern perspective, the biggest upward pressure on snow-day odds is that Rockford and neighboring districts already closed on Wed 2026-01-28 in a broad regional wave—districts often stay aligned when conditions are similar (or when cleanup is still ongoing). The forecast for Thu 2026-01-29 itself is not a classic heavy-snow closure setup (near-zero accumulation), but it *is* a classic “messy commute” setup: pre-dawn freezing rain labeling + extreme cold + reported/forecast low visibility (freezing fog/ice fog). Those ingredients frequently produce 2-hour delays and, less often, full closures—especially if secondary roads and rural bus routes remain slick. Netting those together: I put a modest-but-not-low chance of a full snow day (28%), with the more likely outcome being a delay rather than closure if conditions don’t worsen overnight.
keyFactors: Strong *behavioral/decision* signal: Rockford Public Schools and many peer districts were already closed on Wednesday, 2026-01-28 (per FOX 17 listing). That raises the base rate for a repeat closure/at least a delay if road conditions remain compromised region-wide.

Headline risk for Thu morning is *ice + visibility*, not snowfall: the forecast shows a pre-dawn window labeled “light freezing rain” (roughly 01:00–05:00) plus very cold pavement temps and multiple hours with near-zero visibility/possible freezing fog. Even a trace glaze can cause “bus route” problems on secondary roads.

Recent storm context matters: FOX 17 reporting of heavy snow/whiteout/drifting earlier this week in the Rockford area suggests residual hard-pack and degraded neighborhood/side-road conditions that can persist when temps stay in the single digits/teens.

Counterweight: The *point forecast* for Thu shows minimal new precip and light winds, implying main roads should improve; that tends to favor delays over full-day closures unless the overnight visibility/icing verifies worse than modeled.
No strong ‘infrastructure’ trigger: no meaningful power outage signal; wind is light so widespread outages are unlikely.

debates.topic: Be careful about momentum bias from Wednesday 2026-01-28 closures. A prior-day closure raises sensitivity, but meteorology for Thu is materially different (lighter precip, calmer wind). The decision should hinge on *Thu pre-dawn icing/visibility verification*, not yesterday’s headline volume.
debates.challenge: Be careful about momentum bias from Wednesday 2026-01-28 closures. A prior-day closure raises sensitivity, but meteorology for Thu is materially different (lighter precip, calmer wind). The decision should hinge on *Thu pre-dawn icing/visibility verification*, not yesterday’s headline volume.

debates.topic: The ‘significant’ morning-commute impact rating may be overstated if the freezing rain amounts stay as tiny as forecast (0.01–0.03 mm/hr) and if vis=0 entries are model artifacts. Recommend bounding cases: (1) patchy glaze + localized fog (delay) vs (2) widespread dense freezing fog/icing (closure).

debates.topic: A lot of the visibility fields show 0 miles for many hours; that may be a model/data artifact rather than true dense fog. If visibility is overstated, closure odds drop materially (more like 10–15%). debates.topic: You rate ice formation risk ‘high’ and commute impact ‘significant,’ which is plausible—but the forecast QPF is tiny (precip mm in hundredths). Historically, trace icing often produces delays, not closures, unless it’s widespread and coincident with peak traffic. I’d like to see a clearer mapping from ‘trace glaze risk’ to ‘full closure’ vs ‘delay.’

Otherwise, news context should raise probability modestly, not dominate.

confidenceJourney.shiftReason: Meteorologically, Thu 2026-01-29 looks like a post-event cold, mostly dry day in Rockford with a narrow pre-dawn icing window. That setup more often produces a 2-hour delay than a full closure: impacts are patchy (bridges/side streets) and improve after sunrise, with no heavy snow rates or wind-driven visibility collapse. I’m assigning a non-trivial closure probability mainly because (a) any freezing drizzle at sub-5°F pavement temps can create widespread ‘invisible’ black ice quickly, and (b) the hourly feed’s near-zero visibility signals—if real at 06:00–08:00—can force a conservative call for buses. Still, the lack of meaningful new snow and light winds keeps the closure probability below ~25%.

From a history/precedent lens, Thursday looks like a ‘marginal’ closure setup: very cold, but not extreme-wind-chill cold; minimal new snow; and the main risk concentrated in patchy ice/fog around the early commute. Those scenarios in West Michigan typically lead to a 2-hour delay or selective/rural-route impacts more than a district-wide snow day. The reason I’m still at ~20% (not single digits) is the recent run of closures and degraded baseline conditions—districts sometimes extend caution if residual hard-pack/black ice persists and the overnight glaze verifies.

From a safety standpoint, the forecast does not scream “snow day” on accumulation, but it does present a credible **pre-dawn icing + low-visibility** risk window on Thu 2026-01-29 that can make transportation decisions fail on the margins (buses, student drivers, staff commutes). Because impacts appear **patchy/localized** and likely improve after sunrise, I land in the “more likely delay than closure” zone—yet not low enough to ignore, given the severe cold and visibility flags. Net: ~28% chance of a full snow day/closure, with higher probability for a delay.

From a news/decision-pattern perspective, the biggest upward pressure on snow-day odds is that Rockford and neighboring districts already closed on Wed 2026-01-28 in a broad regional wave—districts often stay aligned when conditions are similar (or when cleanup is still ongoing). The forecast for Thu 2026-01-29 itself is not a classic heavy-snow closure setup (near-zero accumulation), but it *is* a classic “messy commute” setup: pre-dawn freezing rain labeling + extreme cold + reported/forecast low visibility (freezing fog/ice fog). Those ingredients frequently produce 2-hour delays and, less often, full closures—especially if secondary roads and rural bus routes remain slick. Netting those together: I put a modest-but-not-low chance of a full snow day (28%), with the more likely outcome being a delay rather than closure if conditions don’t worsen overnight.

keyDisagreements.topic: Be careful about momentum bias from Wednesday 2026-01-28 closures. A prior-day closure raises sensitivity, but meteorology for Thu is materially different (lighter precip, calmer wind). The decision should hinge on *Thu pre-dawn icing/visibility verification*, not yesterday’s headline volume.

alert.headline: Winter Weather Advisory issued January 28 at 9:35AM EST until January 29 at 10:00AM EST by NWS Grand Rapids MI
alert.desc:
* WHAT...Snow. Additional snow accumulations up to three inches.

* WHERE...Allegan, Ottawaone inch, and Van Buren Counties.

* WHEN...Until 10 AM EST Thursday.

* IMPACTS...Roads, and especially bridges and overpasses, are likely
slick and hazardous. Visibility and road conditions may change
rapidly over short distances in lake effect snow. Plan on slippery
road conditions. The hazardous conditions could impact the
Wednesday evening and Thursday morning commutes.
alert.instruction:
Slow down and use caution while traveling.

During lake effect snow, the weather can vary from bands of locally
heavy snow to dry weather just a few miles away. Visibilities can
also vary greatly. Be prepared for rapid changes in weather,
visibility, and road conditions.

alert.headline: Flood Advisory issued January 27 at 4:05PM EST until January 28 at 7:00PM EST by NWS Grand Rapids MI
alert.desc:
* WHAT...Flooding along the Muskegon River remains possible due to
an ice jam.


* WHERE...A portion of west central Michigan, including the
following county, Newaygo.

* WHEN...Until 700 PM EST Wednesday.

* IMPACTS...Ice jams are notoriously unpredictable. Low-lying areas
along the Muskegon River that are prone to flooding may see
rapidly changing water levels as ice shifts and adjusts.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...
- At 318 PM EST, An ice jam was reported by local authorities
on the Muskegon river in southern Newaygo County. The river
gauge at Newaygo shows water levels remaining at minor flood
stage as of Tuesday afternoon.
- As the river freezes up, ice can restrict the flow of the
river and cause rises and falls in water level. While
flooding associated with freeze up ice jams is typically
minor, conditions can change rapidly and unpredictably.
- Some locations that will experience flooding include...
Newaygo.
- http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
alert.instruction:
Please report observed flooding to local emergency services or law
enforcement and request they pass this information to the National
Weather Service when you can do so safely.
